title: Tissue absence initiates regeneration through Follistatin-mediated inhibition of Activin signaling
abstract: Regeneration is widespread, but mechanisms that activate regeneration remain mysterious. Planarians are capable of whole-body regeneration and mount distinct molecular responses to wounds that result in tissue absence and those that do not. A major question is how these distinct responses are activated. We describe a follistatin homolog (<italic>Smed-follistatin</italic>) required for planarian regeneration. <italic>Smed-follistatin</italic> inhibition blocks responses to tissue absence but does not prevent normal tissue turnover. Two activin homologs (<italic>Smed-activin-1</italic> and <italic>Smed-activin-2</italic>) are required for the <italic>Smed-follistatin</italic> phenotype. Finally, <italic>Smed-follistatin</italic> is wound-induced and expressed at higher levels following injuries that cause tissue absence. These data suggest that Smed-follistatin inhibits Smed-Activin proteins to trigger regeneration specifically following injuries involving tissue absence and identify a mechanism critical for regeneration initiation, a process important across the animal kingdom.
